topic.title: Rotating X.509 certificates
topic.shortdesc: Rotate a certificate when it expires or a widespread breach occurs.

section.title: About certificate rotation
section.p: Certificate rotation is needed before a certificate expires, if you are considering moving to a new CA authority or if a widespread breach of security occurs in the system.

X.509 certificate rotation in Couchbase is an online operation and does not require a node or cluster restart. You can be reassured that the application will have continued access to Couchbase Server without suffering downtime during the rotation operation.

section.title: How to rotate X.509 certificates in Couchbase

dlentry.dt: Generating new certificates using OpenSSL / through your CA
dlentry.dd: Typically, your Certificate Authority (CA) will give you a self-service option to reissue certificates. If this is not the case, you can manually regenerate your new X.509 certificates, and configure them in Couchbase.

dlentry.dt: Deploying certificates on your client machines
dlentry.dd:
You need to configure encryption for client SDKs by:
Loading and importing a certificate from your cluster into the keystore.
Enabling encryption on the client side pointing to the keystore. See Configuring Client SDKs for information.

Certificate rotation depends on its type:
Root CA certificate Rotation: Root certificates usually have a very long life to avoid re-issuing of all certificates for which they are the trusted anchor. The root Certificate Authority (CA) is the topmost CA in a CA hierarchy.
Rotate the root certificate using CLI (example)
Rotate the root certificate using REST (example)
Intermediate certificate rotation: All operating systems and web browsers contain a set of default trusted root certificates. In most deployments, single-tier CA hierarchies are rare, and CA root certificates are not used directly to sign the cluster certificate. Instead, with commonly used N-tier hierarchies, so-called intermediate certificates are used because they can be rotated more frequently than the root CA certificate.

During the development process these external tools might come in handy for verifying and debugging SSL traffic:
openssl: OpenSSL command line tool
wireshark: Network traffic analyzer
nmap: Sophisticated security scanner
You can also view a certificate and verify its content.
If you are using AWS Load Balancers with SSL termination, you can upload the new certificate, key and intermediate certificate by clicking on the Change link under Listeners.
